repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Results Based Management and
            Budgeting Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Results Based Management and Budgeting Project for the
            United Mexican States was judged to be moderately
            unsatisfactory.  The Bank and borrower performance were
            moderately unsatisfactory. The risk to development outcome
            was moderate. Significant changes included revised
            components and project restructuring. Several lessons were
            learned. The instrument was not the best alternative for
            what was needed for these reforms. The mitigation measures
            in place did not lower the risks identified at appraisal.
            This Project benefitted the most from the technical
            assistance and feedback received both during preparation and
            the last years of implementation. In retrospect, it would
            have been better to have supported the Government's
            agenda with a Non-Lending Technical Assistance program or a
            Reimbursable Advisory Services to support more effectively
            the type of reforms the Government was pursuing. Although
            there were mitigation measures in place for this risk, the
            fact that there were two implementing agencies and a
            financial agent was more complex than initially assessed.
            While Components 1 and 2 were very much in line with the
            Government's agenda, both conceptual and technical; the
            components related to results-based budgeting were not
            aligned. This is largely reflected in the lack of
            disbursements throughout the Project. Additional
            implementation support should be considered for projects
            that involve more than one implementing unit that are not
            familiar with large and complex procurement processes.
            Meaningful and objective results indicators are critical for
            monitoring complex reform initiatives. It is optimal to
            ensure alignment between Government processing and the
            Bank's required action. As reflected in the
            Borrower's comments, timely action from the Bank with
            respect to issuing Bank feedback especially "no
            objection" is also a critical element for timely
            implementation. While reform initiatives do not always allow
            for quantifiable measures of success, this project could
            have benefited from a results framework that provided for
            mid-course target values that could have informed
            counterparts and the Bank that mid-course corrections were
            warranted earlier.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Results-Based Management and
            Budgeting Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Results-Based Management and Budgeting Project is to
            establish that federal departments and agencies in Mexico
            provide decision makers and the public with rigorous,
            timely, user-friendly information on the efficiency and
            effectiveness of government organizations and program
            expenditures. This restructuring paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to amend the Project Development
            Objective (PDO) of the project by aligning the PDO to a
            reduced project scope and partial loan cancellation. The
            restructuring will also introduce the following changes: (i)
            the reduction in project scope as a result of changes in
            Government priorities and use of own resources; (ii) the
            revision to the results indicators to align the expected
            results with the activities that will be undertaken under
            the restructured project; (iii) the revision in project
            financing reflecting cancellation of US$12.756 million of
            the loan amount (from US$17.243 million to US$4.4866 million
            including the front-end fee) and revisions to the costs by
            component, financing plan and expenditure categories; and
            (iv) the revisions to the procurement plan and
            implementation schedule as result of the reduction in
            project scope and partial loan cancellation. The
            restructuring will allow achievement of the revised PDO and
            completion of the restructured project within the current
            closing date of December 31, 2013. These changes have been
            approved by management and discussed and agreed with the
            Government of Mexico. The restructuring does not trigger any
            new safeguard policies.
